newsitem.title: USA: Calif. Senate panel OKs $1.4 bln housing bond bill.
newsitem.headline: Calif. Senate panel OKs $1.4 bln housing bond bill.

text.p: A California legislative panel has approved a bill authorizing a state housing agency to issue an additional $1.4 billion of revenue bonds, lawmakers said Thursday.
The Senate Housing Committee approved Assembly Bill 235 by a vote of 5-to-0, referring it to the Senate Appropriations Committee, which was expected to consider the measure in June.
The state Assembly approved the bill, by Republican Assemblyman Nao Takasugi, in April.
The bill increases the maximum mortgage revenue bond debt that the California Housing Financing Agency may issue from $5.35 billion to $6.75 billion.

State officials said this bill would have no direct state fiscal effect because these bonds are not a debt or liability of the state of California. The mortgage revenue bonds are repaid from revenues generated by the California Housing Financing Agency's mortgage loans.
Established in 1975, the agency provides low interest rate capital through the sale of tax-exempt mortgage bonds.

Under current law, the total maximum debt the agency may issue is $5.35 billion. But given the projected bond issuance schedule for 1997-1998, the debt cap must be lifted, supporters of the bill argue.
The $1.4 billion increase in the debt cap proposed by this bill would allow the authority to finance housing for over 20,000 families and single adults in California, it said.
